channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Draghi Announces Further E.C.B. Stimulus Measures, but Investors Are Unimpressed
item.description: The European Central Bank, facing a sluggish eurozone economy, said it would extend the length of its asset purchases and push banks to lend by charging them more to park money.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: To Crush ISIS, John Kerry Urges Deft Removal of Syria’s Assad
item.description: The secretary of state said he believed that if President Bashar al-Assad was carefully removed, America, Russia and Syria’s rebel forces could easily defeat the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Campaign Aims to Attract Russian Tourists
item.description: The campaign was prompted in part by the recent bombing of a Russian airliner in Egypt and the downing of a Russian warplane by Turkey.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Dominican Republic: Court Blocks an Abortion Law
item.description: The law, contested by religious groups, would have decriminalized abortions for the first time, if a pregnant woman’s life was at risk.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Open Source: U.S. Media Mocked Abroad for Reporting False Name of California Shooting Suspect
item.description: Major American news outlets, including The Los Angeles Times and Fox News, were ridiculed on Thursday for apparently falling victim to a hoax.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: World Briefing: Cambodia: Medic Sentenced for Spreading H.I.V.
item.description: An unlicensed medical practitioner was given a 25-year prison term for infecting more than 100 villagers by reusing unsanitized syringes.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Lyft Joins With Asian Rivals to Compete With Uber
item.description: An alliance with GrabTaxi, Ola and Didi Kauidi will give the smaller American ride-hailing company a base in India, China and Southeast Asia.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC
item.media:credit: Stephen Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Zimmer, co-founder and president of Lyft, and Jean Liu, president of DiDi Kuaidi, announced an earlier partnership in September.

item.title: Germany May Offer Model for Reining In Fossil Fuel Use
item.description: Germany reached a milestone last year by reducing its overall energy consumption while still recording modest economic growth of 1.5 percent.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: A wind farm near Berlin. In pursuit of sustainability, Germans have had to pay more for energy, and most support the efforts.

item.title: News Analysis: Faced With Many Crises, Brazil Focuses on Dilma Rousseff’s Impeachment Case
item.description: A faltering economy, an environmental disaster and street protests take a back seat as a powerful lawmaker, Eduardo Cunha — himself facing corruption charges — tries to oust the president.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Eduardo Cunha, center, the president of the Chamber of Deputies of Brazil, listened on Thursday to a reading of the text of the request for impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff.

item.title: Doctors Without Borders Says Clinic Hit in Yemen Was Known to Coalition
item.description: The Saudi-led military coalition bombed the clinic in Taiz, Yemen, wounding nine people less than a week after the medical group shared its coordinates.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Scientists Place Moratorium on Edits to Human Genome That Could Be Inherited
item.description: The moratorium by China, Britain and the United States comes after the invention of a new technique that eases editing of the human genome.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS WADE
item.media:description: David Baltimore, former president of the California Institute of Technology, helped organize an international group of scientists to discuss use of the Crispr-Cas9 technique on human genes.

item.title: Marcus Klingberg, Highest-Ranking Soviet Spy Caught in Israel, Dies at 97
item.description: Mr. Klingberg, an Israeli scientist, was a Soviet spy whose activities were regarded as so damaging that he was imprisoned in secret for years under a false identity.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.media:description: Marcus Klingberg seen in 1996 in Jerusalem during an appeal for early release. It was rejected.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Remembering a Wise Man of Paris
item.description: Ronald Koven, a reporter long based in the city, and an advocate of press freedom, could always be relied on to explain the nuances of French society.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: More Charges as FIFA Inquiry Widens
item.description: Charges against 16 new defendants on Thursday nearly doubled the size of the case that has upended FIFA, soccer’s multibillion-dollar governing body.
item.dc:creator: REBECCA R. RUIZ, MATT APUZZO, SAM BORDEN and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM
item.media:description: A statue at FIFA headquarters in Zurich. The Swiss police arrested more soccer officials on Thursday, widening the corruption scandal.

item.title: Germany Rebukes Its Own Intelligence Agency for Criticizing Saudi Policy
item.description: The German Foreign Ministry repudiated a blunt memo from the BND agency that said Saudi Arabia was playing an increasingly destabilizing role in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Israel Arrests Young Jews Suspected of Terrorism Against Palestinians
item.description: Israeli officials said there were “concrete suspicions” that the people arrested, whose names it did not release, were involved in an arson attack in July.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Egyptian Officials on Defensive Amid Uproar Over Police Brutality Cases
item.description: Allegations of torture by the police have spurred protests and criticism in the media, including from loyalists in a country where officials have been impervious to such criticism.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Ebola Crisis Passes, but Questions on Quarantines Persist
item.description: States often exceeded federal guidelines during the outbreak, sometimes with haphazard consequences, according to a new report.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laura Skrip, a Yale student, in the apartment where she was quarantined after returning from Liberia in October 2014. She had not worked with Ebola patients, but state-imposed restrictions for health workers and other people often exceeded federal guidelines.

item.title: Conflicting Reports on Taliban Leader’s Status Highlight Fraying Unity
item.description: Analysts, while not ruling out the possibility of the shooting of Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour because of rising tensions, said initial details were contradictory at best.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, the supreme leader of the Taliban, in an undated photo.

item.title: Pakistan Sends 30 Migrants Back to Europe
item.description: The asylum seekers were not allowed to disembark from a chartered plane at an Islamabad airport, officials said, reflecting growing frustration with European countries.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD and NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Migrants from Pakistan landing in Kos, Greece, in August. Pakistanis have been among the huge influx of asylum seekers into Europe this year, but they are viewed as economic migrants.
